sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1: Suppose there are four data points given as (1, 3), (2, 9), (4, 7), and (6, 8). Using Lagrange interpolation, find the polynomial function that passes through all the given data points and evaluate the function at x = 3.
message_2:
To find the polynomial function using Lagrange interpolation, we can use the formula:

P(x) = L_0(x) * y_0 + L_1(x) * y_1 + L_2(x) * y_2 + L_3(x) * y_3

where L_i(x) are the Lagrange basis polynomials and y_i are the y-values of the given data points.

The Lagrange basis polynomials are defined as:

L_i(x) = Π((x - x_j) / (x_i - x_j)) for j ≠ i

For our given data points (1, 3), (2, 9), (4, 7), and (6, 8), we can calculate the Lagrange basis polynomials as follows:

L_0(x) = ((x - 2) * (x - 4) * (x - 6)) / ((1 - 2) * (1 - 4) * (1 - 6)) = (x - 2)(x - 4)(x - 6) / 10

L_1(x) = ((x - 1) * (x - 4) * (x - 6)) / ((2 - 1) * (2 - 4) * (2 - 6)) = (x - 1)(x - 4)(x - 6) / (-4)

L_2(x) = ((x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 6)) / ((4 - 1) * (4 - 2) * (4 - 6)) = (x - 1)(x - 2)(x - 6) / 6

L_3(x) = ((x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 4)) / ((6 - 1) * (6 - 2) * (6 - 4)) = (x - 1)(x - 2)(x - 4) / 24

Now we can plug these basis polynomials into the formula for P(x):

P(x) = 3 * L_0(x) + 9 * L_1(x) + 7 * L_2(x) + 8 * L_3(x)

To evaluate the function at x = 3, we plug in x = 3 into P(x):

P(3) = 3 * L_0(3) + 9 * L_1(3) + 7 * L_2(3) + 8 * L_3(3)

P(3) = 3 * ((3 - 2)(3 - 4)(3 - 6) / 10) + 9 * ((3 - 1)(3 - 4)(3 - 6) / (-4)) + 7 * ((3 - 1)(3 - 2)(3 - 6) / 6) + 8 * ((3 - 1)(3 - 2)(3 - 4) / 24)

P(3) = 3 * ((1)(-1)(-3) / 10) + 9 * ((2)(-1)(-3) / (-4)) + 7 * ((2)(1)(-3) / 6) + 8 * ((2)(1)(-1) / 24)

P(3) = 3 * (3 / 10) - 9 * (6 / 4) - 7 * (6 / 6) + 8 * (-2 / 24)

P(3) = 0.9 - 13.5 - 7 + (-0.6667)

P(3) ≈ -20.2667

So, the polynomial function evaluated at x = 3 is approximately -20.2667.
